What is Scala Programming?

Scala is a high-level programming language which is a combination of object-oriented programming and functional programming. It is highly scalable which is why it is called Scala.

June 02, 2018      4674 Views     3 Comments

Scala is one of the new languages that is based on the Java Virtual Machine compatibility. It has a lot of similarities and differences as compared to the Java programming language. Scala is slowly finding a lot of acceptance among developers around the world due to its certain inherent strengths. One of the best resemblances of Scala to Java is that you can code Scala just the same way that you code Java. It is also possible to use a lot of the Java libraries within Scala along with many of the third party libraries as well.

Learn Scala in 24 hrs. Download e-book now

Download

X

Scala Programming

Scala programming is a general-purpose computer language that extensively supports the object oriented, and functional style of programming. Scala language is a strong static type of programming language. Scala is influenced by the Java programming language.

Scala is very versatile in the sense that it can be used for writing any type of applications like web application, desktop application, mobile application, enterprise application and so on.

Some of the ways in which Scala language is deployed in real world scenarios is as follows :

  • Writing web applications
  • Applications working with streaming data
  • Distributed applications
  • Parallel batch processing
  • Analyzing data with Apache Spark

Some of the benefits of Scala is that it takes less time to code as compared to Java which needs more lines of code. Scala also has the benefit of strong tools and APIs that can be used for creating various applications.

Sample Scala Program

“Hello World” example

object HelloWorld extends App

{

println(“Hello, World!”)

}

Meaning of Scala js

The Scala.js is a compiler that is equal to the JavaScript code and it compiles the Scala source code. This way it is possible to write the Scala code that can be run in a web browser or any other environment where there is a support for JavaScript.

Definition of Scala list

The Scala List is a stored order element. It consists of a class of immutable linked list and this class is follows the norm of List in First out (LIFO). It access pattern is stack-like pattern. When it comes to the Scala List there are duplicate elements and it always maintains the order of the elements.

Why do we need Scala?

In this comprehensive Scala Tutorial you will learn that Scala is a powerful language that exhibits both the properties of object oriented programming and functional programming. There are a lot of advantages of Scala that makes it one of the best languages for working with big data and real-time analytical applications.

Wish to Learn Scala? Click Here

Some of Scala advantages include :

  • Your code is more concise, readable and error-free
  • It is easy to write, compile, debug and run the program
  • Functional programming lets you approach same problem through different angle
  • Deploy concurrency which helps in parallelizing the tasks
  • You can utilize a lot of third-party libraries for specific tasks

Functional Programming in Scala

As everyone knows that Scala is a functional programming language we need to understand the intricacies of a functional programming language. One of the main aspects of a functional programming language is that there is a big emphasis on the functions that are not dependent on the program state. One of the advantages of functional programming is that the code is easier to test and reuse, the parallelization becomes simpler, and there are lesser bugs in the whole program. In the functional programming style each of the programs is broken down into multiple chunks and each one can be processes in parallel thus speeding up the process and also improving the efficiency.

What is Scala Seq?

Scala Seq or Scala sequence is a quality that signifies the indexed sequencing in Scala and which is immutable. With the help of the index, each element can be easily accessed. The order in which the element is inserted is maintained. We can see the Scala seq as a type of iterative collections that have a defined element order. The indices can range anywhere between zero to the length of the sequence. In order to find the occurrence of an element the sequence supports various methods like indexWhere, startsWith, endsWith, prefixLength and so on.

There are a lot of other features of Scala that can be used wherein the various aspects of this technology can be explored to the fullest. One of the important components of the Scala language is Scala IDE which is Scala Integrated Development Environment and this is used to connected to the Eclipse Java tool. This way the Eclipse features can explored with the Scala IDE. The Scala development can be easily achieved thanks to the Scala IDE.

Scala programming language is an object oriented language with functional programming language features that is highly scalable and devised to the programming expressions in a precise and safe manner. It is named after its feature of ‘scalability’ which separates it from other programming languages. In a nutshell, Scala is a pure-bred object-oriented programming language inculcating the features of functional languages.

Developed by Martin Odersky, the first version of Scala was launched in the year 2003 and is running successfully since then.

“We’ve found that Scala has enabled us to deliver things faster with less code. It’s reinvigorated the team.”- Graham Tackley, The Guardian

Comparison Between Scala and Java

There is a simple question that every developer should know as to why should he go for it instead of Java? Following comparison will help you make your decision:

Java Scala
Complex syntax Simple syntax
Requires lengthy codes to be written. Shorter codes for the same purpose.
Rewriting is needed. Rewriting is not required.
Dynamic in nature Statically-typed
No assurance of bug-free codes Assurance of Lesser defects

Scala and Java are the two of the most important programming languages that have come our way. Though there are a lot of similarities between the two languages there are a lot of differences as well. So here we will delve into the aspects of Scala and Java and so what are the distinctions between the two and such other aspects. Java is a very old language and Scala is relatively new. The Scala language does need the Java Virtual Machine or JVM at the compilation stage in order to run the Scala programming applications that are supported by the JavaScript.

Java is basically an object oriented language and a very good one at that. Scala on the other hand is a machine compiled language. Java is mostly used for data gathering and manipulation and this makes the data available to the users with the help of graphic user interface and object oriented patterns. Scala in the strict sense is a functional style of programming. Scala can run only on a specific environment and this it depends of the Java Virtual Machine. With the help of a compiler the Scala language can offer the object oriented functionality and the type system is statistically scanned during the compilation time just like Java.

Scala differs from Java in the sense that Scala is a functional programming language whereas Java is an object oriented programming language. Scala has the facility to work in a multi-core architecture environment. Today it is all about the trend of adding more cores instead of going for increased CPU cycles, thus the functional programming helps for this shift thoroughly.

Scala when compared to Java has enhanced code readability and conciseness. Java has always be accused of being too lengthy when it comes to the size of code. What is written in Java in a certain lines of code can actually be written in Scala in half the number of lines of code.

Scala has a special feature which is called as lazy evaluation which is the property of delaying the computation of tasks till the time when it is actually needed. This is also called as call-by-need evaluation where in only when the value is needed, the actual evaluation of the expression starts. This benefits in the way that there is no redundant evaluation. Due to this the performance can be improved by avoiding all the calculations that are not needed.

Having outlined all these benefits of Scala over Java, you must have gotten a clear picture why it is trending nowadays at such a pace. Some of the larger companies of present time such as Twitter, LinkedIn, Intel, etc., rely on this programming language for developing large products. What makes it so special over other available programming languages?

  • It is object-oriented in nature.
  • Includes functional programming features as well.
  • Reflects concurrent and synchronize processing ability.

This language is based on the concept of object-oriented programming as each value is considered as an object and each operation a method-call. It also uses classes and traits to classify the objects. Additionally this language allows you to expand the existing classes by adding more operations regardless of the sources, i.e., Java or Scala. It also includes the feature of multiple-inheritance by extending the sub-classing. Having said that it is clear that each function acts as an object. It provides function for various uses such as for defining anonymous functions, supporting higher-order functions, nesting functions, etc. Unlike the traditional functional languages, it provides a swift way of shifting to more functional style. This makes it easy to implement most of the times.

Want to know What is Scala? Read this extensive tutorial!

It runs on JVM and is compiled into java Byte Codes, which clearly implies that Java and Scala have the same platform. These byte codes after getting compiled on JVM are executed with the help of Scala commands that are quite similar to Java commands. The tools, frameworks and IDEs that work on Java work smoothly on Scala. It runs on JVM as well as Android which makes it a preferable choice for web framework. Scala runs both own classes as well the custom Java classes without paying attention to the source these are taken from.

It proves to be a convenient programming language when it comes to developing large server programs. It simplifies programming by allowing you to express the codes in minimum possible lines and immutable manner making it suitable for both the concurrent a well as synchronized processing.

Finally it is not only easier than Java, it is entertaining to code programs as well. Lesser rapid iterations make it a strong and comprehensible programming language.

Download latest questions asked on Scala in top MNC's ?

Scope of Scala

Since its inception, Scala has witnessed tremendous growth in its demand, which is forecasted to increase in the near future. Some of the statistics are mentioned below to support the aforementioned statement:

  • 88% of developers use Scala, 22% use python, and 44% use Java for Spark programming. –Lightbend
  • Scala has surprisingly shown 77% growth in the year 2014 from the previous year. -KDnuggets

With these growing numbers it can be claimed that Scala is one of the booming technologies in present scenario as major tech players are implementing it in their architecture.

Despite struggling among the established languages like Java and Python, Scala has made its own niche delivering high-end productivity and performance over the years.

Who should learn Scala?

With growing requirement of professionals who would be experts in both functional as well as object-oriented programming, Scala programmers and engineers will definitely make it big in this market. Moreover if you are well-acquainted with Java, C++, C and Python, Scala would be the perfect choice for you to improve your programming skills and get better career opportunities at the same time.

It is best suited technology for aspiring software professionals, Data Scientists, Data Engineers and Analytics Professionals.

How will Scala help you in career growth?

It is not only an easy and less tedious programming language, it is widely used by some of the biggest companies like Twitter, LinkedIn, FourSquare, etc., for implementing their platforms. Following trends will give a clearer view :

  • A report by Techcrunch.com shows that after Rust, Swift and F#, Scala is fourth most demanded programming language in the world of technology.

  • According to a survey conducted by Indeed.com, the job postings for Scala professionals are constantly increasing since 2012.

This definitely gives a fair idea why the candidates should learn this programming language in order to grab the best job opportunities.

Gradually the companies are realizing that it is not merely a programming language, but a medium to improve their existing software products. Its ability to give the developers the strength to code in their familiar programming language has taken it to a new height. Its strength to collaborate functional and object-oriented programming under one roof has given it lots of accolades in the domain of technology.

With this increase in the demand for Scala, the companies are fervently looking for professionals having good command of this programming language, which signifies that numerous lucrative career opportunities are awaiting the aspirants wanting to make their careers in big data world.
